title: Newcastle Emily van Egmond makes 150th appearance for the Matildas | Newcastle Herald
body_text:
Emily van Egmond joined illustrious company in Brisbane on Thursday night, making her 150th appearance for the Matildas.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
In doing so, the Dudley Redhead United Football Club junior, joined only three other players to reach the milestone along with Lisa De Vanna (150 caps), Newcastle legend Cheryl Salisbury (151) and the retiring Clare Polkinghorne (168).
The 31-year-old van Egmond has been a constant in Australia's women's side since debuting as a fresh-faced 16-year-old in March, 2010.
The San Diego Wave midfielder looked as reliable as ever in a 67-minute performance before being replaced by Tameka Yallop in the Matildas' 3-1 loss to Brazil in what was a not-so-friendly international.
The question is, can van Egmond push on and become the country's most-capped women's player in history?
She needs another 18 appearances to equal Polkinghorne, whose career was celebrated in front of a sold-out crowd on Thursday night.
The Queenslander is 35 years old. Salisbury was 34 when she hung up her boots as one Australia's greatest ever player in 2009.
After Polkinghorne steps aside, van Egmond will be the most experienced player in the Matildas' squad.
She has played at four World Cups and three Olympics but is yet to claim a medal at a major tournament, and that could prove a driving force in the next few years.
In 150 appearances, van Egmond has also notched 31 goals and her versatility as a deep-lying midfielder or attacking option should continue to make her an integral part of Australia's squad for years to come.
The Newcastle Jets product overcame a debilitating back injury to be one of the Matildas' best at the 2023 World Cup, where they fell short of a medal but captured the hearts and minds of a nation.
On Thursday night, van Egmond played a part in Australia's only goal with a clever fake in the box to put Caitlin Foord in the path of Ellie Carpenter's killer pass.
"You never know what can happen in football," van Egmond told the Newcastle Herald leading into this year's Paris Olympics.
"Every tournament, every time you get the chance to represent your country, you treat it like it is your last."
Van Egmond had 129 caps for her country leading into the World Cup in July last year so could potentially surpass Polkinghorne's mark with another couple of years in the Matildas' frame.
By the end of this international window, she could be the second-most-capped player of all time.
The Matildas get another shot at Brazil on the Gold Coast on Sunday night before flying to Victoria next week for two games against Chinese Taipei.
Van Egmond was blunt in her assessment of the Matildas' result and performance on Thursday night in a game that turned fiery against an extremely physical Brazil.
The match grew in intensity with Foord and Hayley Raso particularly incensed by their treatment. The Brazilians finished with 10 players after Vitoria Calhau was sent off in the 86th minute for a second yellow-card offence.
"We need to be able to match it, and we need to be better," van Egmond said.
Amanda Gutierres struck in the sixth and 13th minutes at Suncorp Stadium to bring Australia undone in front of 47,501 fans.
Foord finished off a wonderful team goal in the 43rd minute but Atletico Madrid winger Gio rounded out Brazil's win in the 54th.
Newcastle's Clare Wheeler, who plays for Everton in England's Women's Super League, was one of four players to withdraw from a 36-player squad named by interim Matildas coach Tom Sermanni.
Wheeler (leg) and Gorry (shoulder) withdrew due to injuries. Cortnee Vine was unavailable due to personal reasons and Mary Folwer cited mental and physical fatigue after a heavy playing schedule.
Newcastle Jets centre-back Natasha Prior, who has received her first Matildas call-up, was one of 12 substitutes on the bench on Thursday night but did not take the pitch.
The 26-year-old is among a wave of new talent included in an extended squad.
Queensland duo Winonah Heatley and Sharn Freier, both 23, showed why they are two of the Matildas' most promising members of the next generation with strong performances against Brazil.
Heatley, playing as a defensive midfielder, had her first start in the national team and did not look out of place.
With the home Asian Cup on the horizon, Sermanni said it was the right time to bring young players into the squad.
